>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
>
>John, thanks for the unhyped explanation of Thaler.  Admittedly, I
>know nothing about it otherwise, but from your description it sounds
>like simple hill climbing, i.e. make a tweak, see if you improved,
>and if not go back to where you were.  Is there any real
>difference?  Hill climbing is known to get stuck on local
>optima...well that's an understatenent...it *does* get stuck on
>local optima.  That's one reason having a population is helpful.
>So I am just wondering how Thaler's thing differs from hill climbing?

As far as I have gathered, it isn't.  But because he is climbing the CURRENT 
hill, he may avoid some of those pitfalls.  Instead of taking a look at the 
landscape of 100 input samples and then walking in the 'average' uphill, it 
walks up the hill of the current situation.  For a real-world situation, the 
fitness landscape would tend to move fairly smoothly, shifting the peak (for 
example) left and right, and so the hill climber is constantly following 
that peak.  Yes, it could get caught in a local optima...until it finds a 
situation in which that optima is far from optimal, which could jolt it out 
of that optima with enough force to let it find a better optima somewhere 
else.  That is how his robotic controller works, anyway.

The self-training network is nothing more than a network that implements 
back-propagation on itself.  Not really that earth-shattering.

The creativity machine is nothing more than an exploration of the space 
around the error-minimized solution.  The base network represents a 
mathematical model of a problem space.  For a given input, it has a given 
output.  But making minor tweaks to the model lets you explore the 
surrounding environment.  You get things that are closely related to the 
original model, with the mathematical shape of the tweak being almost the 
same, but just enough different that you get a 'novel' output that is often 
relevant and appropriate.

I think having a random input node would be an improvement even to Thaler's 
work.  The connection weight will encapsulate the width of the 'relevance' 
range that is viable to explore.  Then, the network will always tend to give 
'creative' but relevant output.

>I agree with what Derek later said...that site is so full of hype
>and hyperbole that I can hardly believe this guy is really on the
>ball and not just a nut.  But then again, they say genius is
>difficult recognize...

Someone that is dependant on and trying to attract investors is left with 
little choice.  They have to make a good impression on people with the cash. 
  And what works on them doesn't always work on the people with the 
knowledge and understanding of the work being done.  That, and what he is 
doing is easily reproduced, which he would prefer not to have happen.  So he 
doesn't spell out the details, for fear of being copied.  Can't blame the 
guy for that. :)
